content: The "Drug Free Sports Act" defines terms like "Secretary" and "professional sports associations" and mandates mandatory drug testing for athletes. The "Drug Free Sports Act" mandates professional sports associations to implement drug testing policies for athletes, including random testing at least once a year. The professional sports association conducts random drug tests on athletes throughout the year without prior notification. The Secretary issues a list of prohibited substances for testing, determined by the World Anti-Doping Agency and deemed performance-enhancing by the Secretary. The professional sports association conducts random drug tests on athletes throughout the year without prior notification. The Secretary issues a list of prohibited performance-enhancing substances for testing. Tests are administered by an independent party, and a positive test results in suspension from participation. An athlete testing positive for prohibited substances faces a minimum 2-year suspension from professional sports, with a permanent ban for repeat offenders. Suspensions include loss of pay. An athlete testing positive for prohibited substances faces a minimum 2-year suspension from professional sports, with a permanent ban for repeat offenders. All suspensions result in a loss of pay. The name of any athlete with a positive test result must be disclosed to the public. Athletes have the right to appeal and must file within 5 days of learning about the positive test. The professional sports association must hold a hearing and reach a final decision within 30 days of receiving notice. The association must hold a hearing and make a final decision within 30 days of receiving notice of an appeal, with penalties being stayed pending the final adjudication. The Secretary has the authority to exempt professional sports associations from regulations if they already have policies for testing athletes for prohibited substances that meet or exceed the requirements. Beginning 1 year after the final rules are issued, the Secretary can fine professional sports associations $5,000,000 for not following testing policies. The fine can increase by $1,000,000 per day of noncompliance. The Secretary must provide a report every 2 years on the effectiveness of regulations and compliance by professional sports associations. Additionally, the Comptroller General will conduct a study on college and secondary school testing policies and procedures. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the use of performance-enhancing substances by college and secondary school athletes, focusing on prohibited substance policies and testing procedures of athletic associations, university departments, and interscholastic associations. A report is due within 1 year. The Comptroller General will assess the effectiveness of testing policies for detecting performance-enhancing substances in college and secondary school athletes. A report with recommendations to Congress is due within 1 year.
